name: TheAtlantic
text: "Conventions have long been 'hot'—loud, unsubtle, the political version of infomercials. The Democrats were forced by the pandemic to be cool, and every political gathering from now on will have to reckon with how effective they were" writes @JamesFallows: https://t.co/Hpx6qMrNK0

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @emmaogreen: Read my story about one of the most consequential races coming up in November, which will test whether Georgia is ready to elect its first Black senator and embrace a different, distinctly non-Trumpian view of the Bible: 
https://t.co/diFsbyFqVD

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @ibogost: Every city looks the same now. @Oniropolis explains how it got this way, and why a new commitment to local vernacular style would improve the livability, and sustainability, of global cities.

https://t.co/SJHnSiubhf

name: TheAtlantic
text: In this week’s "Dear Therapist," @lorigottlieb1 advises a reader whose husband keeps offending her extended family with rude comments and standoffish behavior: https://t.co/RUmmHkjKDi

name: TheAtlantic
text: For decades, broadcast TV commercials often held the same pop-cultural legitimacy as the programming they ran against. Now they're widely maligned—and quickly vanishing, @MacSchwerin writes. https://t.co/zhGqOPyXzM
